column4: So, not paying attention to what I've purchased, I've recently realized my laptop is 64 bit.  I'm wondering, is there a clean upgrade path from 32-bit ubuntu to 64-bit ubuntu?
is there a usable upgrade path?
So, do you know of some reasonable 'install-over' instructions for a debian based distribution?
You mean besides just popping in the CD?  sure.
Well, I mean, keeping all the stuff I have installed and so on...
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Installation has a bunch of stuff sans CD.  Keeping all your stuff.  do you have a separate home partition?
that'll work regardless of the distro (since its just package names)
Yes, but I want to keep my apps too.
You'll have to reinstall them, and find 64bit versions for them.  Or run them in a32bit chroot.
why do you want to do that?
sshfs and conflicting uids between systems
Ah.  Unfortunately not that I'm aware of.  Supposed to just keep UIDs the same ;)
there may be another way, I don't know of it though.
If you're worried about it, stick with Hardy.  You can upgrade to 10.04 (the next LTS) in 2010
